text: I was tasked with creating an ebook all about the ecommerce ecosystem to launch in the first month of me joining (taught me a lot about the space as well as how to use our tools like HubSpot). It's also a requirement in our onboarding to listen to sales demos and customer success calls - gave me an in-depth understanding of the product

text:
Hey! I'm writing an article about free downloads/lead magnets on the Ninja Forms blog. If anyone has any experience with offering free downloads (a plus if you're in the WordPress space/using WordPress for CMS), I would love to include some quotes about why you're doing it and/or how it affects your email list.

Thank you :grin:

text:
I was offered a freelance contract to write blogs for an agency that provides them for their clients, and I was _appalled_ at the rates they were paying. This includes doing any/all research (including SEO) on my own in addition to writing the article.
• $16 for 500 words
• $28 for 1000 words
• $38 for 1500 words
• $50 for 2000 words
Are my expectations too high, or are these rates pretty low?  If you use freelancers, what is your typical/average payment for similar projects?  If you’re a freelancer, would you take this job and/or what are you average rates?

As I’m looking to get more freelance writing/editing gigs, any and all information and advice in this area is welcome and appreciated.

Thank you in advance!!

appalled
at the rates they were paying. This includes doing any/all research (including SEO) on my own in addition to writing the article.

$38 for 1500 words
$50 for 2000 words

Are my expectations too high, or are these rates pretty low?  If you use freelancers, what is your typical/average payment for similar projects?  If you’re a freelancer, would you take this job and/or what are you average rates?

As I’m looking to get more freelance writing/editing gigs, any and all information and advice in this area is welcome and appreciated.

Thank you in advance!!

text: Even at agency rates, that stinks.

elements.text: Even at agency rates, that stinks.

text: Yeah, these are abysmal

elements.text: Yeah, these are abysmal

text: Woah, those rates are so low! I had to re-read a couple of times :sweat_smile: I hire freelancers, and pay anywhere from $1,000-$2,000 for blog posts & whitepapers (1,800-5,000 words). We're in a really technical/niche space, though, so those are likely on the high side.

elements.text: Woah, those rates are so low! I had to re-read a couple of times
I hire freelancers, and pay anywhere from $1,000-$2,000 for blog posts & whitepapers (1,800-5,000 words). We're in a really technical/niche space, though, so those are likely on the high side.

text: These rates tell you what the content is worth to them. This is not a highly valued or high ROI initiative, which means you're not going to get a lot of experience OR money from taking it on. Pass.

elements.text: These rates tell you what the content is worth to them. This is not a highly valued or high ROI initiative, which means you're not going to get a lot of experience OR money from taking it on. Pass.

text: Is it possible two 0s are missing from every price listed, though? It's worth checking on that, haha!

elements.text: Is it possible two 0s are missing from every price listed, though? It's worth checking on that, haha!

text: What? That's freakishly low. I think I've seen those rates somewhere. Is it The Hog? They pay terribly low.

elements.text: What? That's freakishly low. I think I've seen those rates somewhere. Is it The Hog? They pay terribly low.

text: Yikes. For reference I've a project on the go and a 1,500-2,000 word whitepaper will be the final output. Billings are over $1K currently for the words alone, and that doesn't include the agency markup (just my bill to the agency who will likely add some points to the end client). And there is still work yet to be done!

text: I have heard of folks who take these kinds of rates on platforms like Upwork and they can manage to make a decent hourly since they can crank them out. That is definitely not my writing process, though, lol

elements.text: I have heard of folks who take these kinds of rates on platforms like Upwork and they can manage to make a decent hourly since they can crank them out. That is definitely not my writing process, though, lol

text: Their rates don't even warrant a response IMO. It's disrespectfully low. I work with tons of freelancers and for a 1,000 word blog article as an example, the bottom end would be $200. Quality piece with research, quotes, images... $500 range. Unless the content generates leads or direct customer acquisition things generally top out around there. Some freelancers will definitely charge more, and can get paid more, each gig will be different and each company has different budgets. From what I've seen using platforms like WriterAccess, the platform can take up to 30% of the content fee, so if the company is paying 10cents/word... you're making 7cents/word. This agency is potentially either A) working with clients who have paper thin budgets so they have no other option to pay poorly B) they are taking a decent portion of the costs billed to their client and screwing the content creator to increase their margins.

text: Run. Run as as far as you can. Those rates are disrespectful to your time and experiences. I work in B2B content marketing (in-house) but we do hire freelancers. On average we pay $800 for 700-100 $1000 for 1000-1200 words

elements.text: Run. Run as as far as you can. Those rates are disrespectful to your time and experiences. I work in B2B content marketing (in-house) but we do hire freelancers. On average we pay $800 for 700-100 $1000 for 1000-1200 words

text:
if you have the possibility then work half a day or even a day in other teams. Advantage there is:
1. you get to know the people faster
2. see different processes
3. maybe see potential to optimize processes
4. you can get get in touch with customers (very important).
This helped me a lot the better unterstand how the company works and how they want you to work.

Make bookmarks in your internet browser with the tools the company works, to be faster.

Check out performance dashboards if there are ones. (if now, do it yourself)

In this covid situation: make 15min coffee brakes with your new colleagues. You can get to know each other better and understand their work faster.

text: The lowest I've ever paid for freelance writers was during a few months in 2007 when the site I was running had just gone online, and even back during those early days I paid $100 for 750 words. Almost 15 years ago I paid four times this rate!!

text: I really hope they don’t keep doing that “take your right to the sentence” kind of thing. Very few searches are solved with a zero-context sentence or short paragraph.

text:
We typically pay in the $0.18-0.30 per word range, depending on the client, budget, complexity of topic, etc. Although we offer project-based rates, not per word rates (but our typical rates for projects reflect this range).

Edit: Yeah, those rates are laughably low. I’d pay my dog more to walk all over a keyboard.

text:
Yikes - echoing what others have said. That's content mill rates.

A newbie content writer with even just 1 or 2 samples they created on their blog should be able to charge at least $75 - $100 USD for a short-form post.

text:
Hey team! What's your favorite way to *turn a podcast into a blog*? I've seen a few formats:

• Journalistic overview with direct quotes from the founder who was interviewed?
• Going hyper-focused on one idea that was presented, then expanding on it?
• "Regular" article that's washed of any reference to the podcast, just all the value totally repackaged?
I'd love to hear your thoughts (and see some examples)!

elements.text: Hey team! What's your favorite way to
turn a podcast into a blog
? I've seen a few formats:
Journalistic overview with direct quotes from the founder who was interviewed?
Going hyper-focused on one idea that was presented, then expanding on it?
"Regular" article that's washed of any reference to the podcast, just all the value totally repackaged?
I'd love to hear your thoughts (and see some examples)!

text:
I’ve heard from listeners that they appreciate a short writeup with takeaways from the episode. It also creates the opportunity to link to bigger posts about a specific mentioned in the episode.

Here’s an example of how I did that with my convo with Jimmy

<https://stewarthillhouse.com/jimmy-daly/>

attachments.title: The Path To Making $100K+ As A Content Marketer with Jimmy Daly
attachments.text: The job of a content marketer is not to write blog posts. Your job is to support the business. Jimmy Daly joins Stewart Hillhouse on Top Of Mind Podcast
attachments.fallback: Stewart Hillhouse: The Path To Making $100K+ As A Content Marketer with Jimmy Daly

text: Has anyone seen a great post about distribution strategies for content? I am a fan of John Bonini's Some Good Content (loved his GTM template from last fall) and also the Animalz content - but I think I am looking for something a bit more tactical, and a way to frame our content distribution strategy when I have multiple assets that are hitting different parts of the funnel (TOFU, MOFU, BOFU) and am thinking of all the different teams who play a role in distribution (PR, Demand Gen, Social, Dev Evangelism, etc.). Any tips/suggestions/frameworks would be welcome!

text:
Hey everyone:wave::skin-tone-4:,

What do you think is one important step marketers overlook when building a content distribution strategy? 

What companies have incredible distribution strategies in your opinion?

I'm writing a guest post for PR Fire and I'm looking for quotes that could help give my readers new information that isn't available in existing posts. 

Would be glad to link back to any site of your choice. Thank you.

text: Find communities where their customers hang out and build relationships. Leaders of these communities are always trying to present value for their members. If trust has been established your content can be the fuel that educates these groups.

elements.text: Find communities where their customers hang out and build relationships. Leaders of these communities are always trying to present value for their members. If trust has been established your content can be the fuel that educates these groups.

text: We are trying to bake distribution into our content creation process so we can be more intentional — but I still feel like we may be missing opportunities. Right now, we have a list of channels that we run through and decide which have the most potential for a given piece. For example, our posts featuring templates do well on LinkedIn and in lifecycle emails, while thought leadership with a point of view sparks conversations on Twitter. And we try to leverage partners with large social followings / newsletter lists as much as possible.

text: I’m not a fan of it either

elements.text: I’m not a fan of it either

text:
An important step marketers overlook is not setting up a link tracker for content distribution.

Marketers should set up a link tracker to know how each distribution platforms performs compared to others.

You'll be surprised that some of these platforms aren't generating any engagement. Link tracking will help you know which platforms you should double-down on.

WpBeginner has a solid distribution strategy. Besides the blog, WpBeginner has a youtube channel where they re-create make videos around their content.

Videos are always inserted within the blogs and links to the article is always included in the YouTube description.

WpBeginner also redistribute to other platforms like Facebook, Pinterest, Twitter, etc.
